Award.AwardTitle: New Developments on Quantile Regression Analysis of Censored Data: Theory, Methodology and Computation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Quantile regression has recently emerged as a valuable semiparametric alternative to the popular Cox model for analyzing censored data. It directly models survival time; thus is easy to interpret. More importantly, it relaxes the proportional hazards constraint associated with the Cox model and is particularly powerful for heterogeneous data. Despite the remarkable recent progress, several important and challenging statistical problems remain unsolved. For example, there exists limited literature on censored quantile regression when the sample arises from an observational study and is not representative of the target population; when the censored data come from genomics studies involving high-dimensional covariates; or when random effects are present due to the incorporation of latent variables. Motivated by these challenging problems, this project will develop novel methodology, theory and algorithms, which have the potential to significantly advance the applications of censored quantile regression. The PI will rigorously study the theoretical properties of the proposed new procedures and investigate their applications in practical data analysis.

Censored data arise in diverse fields such as economics, engineering, medicine, psychology and sociology. The new methodology and theory are expected to make important contributions to the current body of knowledge on statistical analysis of survival data. In particular, the proposed research will make timely contributions to high-dimensional data analysis with censored responses, which has important applications in modern genomics and is still a relatively unexplored research area. The PI will develop useful software packages and make them freely available to the research community. The research results will be incorporated in different levels of statistical courses. The PI will also incorporate her research activity with graduate education. Students from minority groups will be especially encouraged to participate in the proposed projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Censored data arise in diverse fields such as economics, engineering, medicine, psychology and sociology. For example, in clinical trials, censoring occurs when the study ends before all patients experience the event of interest. Some patients may drop out because they move
out of the area or because they experience adverse side effects. In sociology and economics, censored data are common in the studies of divorce, arrests, job stability, unemployment duration, among others. As the time to the event of interest is not observed if the observation
is censored, statistical analysis without appropriately accounting for censoring typically results in biased estimation and inference.

Recently, quantile regression has emerged as a powerful and flexible approach for analyzing censored data. Quantile regression does not require to specify the likelihood function and relaxes the proportional hazards constraint associated with the popular Cox model. It models the conditional quantile of the survival time and is easy to interpret. When the censoring is heavy, it can be difficult to estimate the mean survival time accurately but it is often possible to reliably estimate the median and the lower quantiles. More importantly, quantile regression can incorporate heterogeneity that cannot be naturally accommodated by the Cox model.

 

Despite the remarkable recent progress on quantile regression analysis of censored data, some important and challenging statistical problems still remain unsolved. For example, there exists little or no literature on censored quantile regression when the sample arises
from an observational study and is not representative of the target population; when the censored data come from genomics studies involving high-dimensional covariates. Motivated by these challenges and related important applications, the PI and her students and collaborators have developed novel methodology, theory and algorithms that apply to high-dimensional quantile regression which have the potential to significantly advance the applications of censored quantile regression. Furthermore, the PI and her collaborators have developed censored quantile regression for both length-biased survival data and censored data under more general biased sampling scheme.

 

The findings of the PI will provide scientists in many different disciplines with new and flexible tools for analyzing data with heterogeneity and censoring. The outcomes of the project include the following publications:

 

(1)  Xu, G. J., Sit, T., Wang, L. and Huang, C-Y. (2016+) Quantile regression under general biased sampling scheme.  To appear in Journal of the American Statistical Association.

(2)  Wang, L. and Sherwood, B. (2016+) Invited discussion on “Posterior inference in Bayesian quantile regression with asymmetric Laplace likelihood" by Yang, Wang

and He, to appear in International Statistical Review.

(3)  Wang, L. (2016+) Nonconvex penalized quantile regression: a review of methods, theory and algorithms for high-dimensional hetergoneous data analysis. Invited book chapter for Handbook of Quantile Regression.

(4)  Sherwood, B. and Wang, L.  (2016) Partially linear additive quantile regression in ultra-high dimension. Annals of Statistics, 44, 288-317.

(5)  Peng, B. and Wang, L. (2015) An iterative coordinate-descent algorithm for high-dimensional nonconvex penalized quantile regression. Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics, 24(3), 676-694.

(6)  Wey, A., Wang, L. and Rudser, K.  (2014) Censored quantile regression with recursive partitioning based weights.  Biostatistics, 15, 170-181.

(7)  Wang, H. X. and Wang. L. (2014)  Quantile regression analysis of length-biased survival data. Stat, 3, 31-47.
